Mr. Ferland’s practice includes regular contributions to catastrophic designation assessment teams where he provides opinions related to daily function of individuals suffering from serious physical, psychological and cognitive impairments.   His assessments inform multidisciplinary team   members   (psychiatry, orthopedics, neurology, physiatry, psychology, etc.) of injured client’s daily functional capabilities at home, work and in the community, assisting them in forming opinions surrounding whether the catastrophic injury threshold is met. ASSESSMENT PREAMBLE:  This   in-home   assessment   was   conducted   to   evaluate   Ms.   Veronique   Slykhuis's   current functional abilities and limitations following injuries sustained in a motor vehicle collision on August 26, 2023. The assessment was requested by her legal representative, Mr. Paul Mooney of Badre Law Professional Corporation, to:  ●   Complete an updated in-home assessment addressing current functional status  ●   Evaluate ongoing attendant care needs  ●   Provide   recommendations   regarding   additional   occupational   therapy   services   and equipment needs  ●   Identify other services that may assist in recovery  ●   Provide commentary on Catastrophic Impairment spheres of function (AMA Guides 2014)  SUMMARY OF FINDINGS:  Ms. Slykhuis is a 50-year-old woman who sustained serious injuries in a motor vehicle collision on August 26, 2023, when she was a belted passenger in a vehicle struck at high speed on the passenger side. The impact caused the vehicle to spin and land in a ditch, with her 17-year-old son arriving at the scene. The collision resulted in significant physical trauma including left breast hematomas requiring surgical aspiration, a displaced left rib fracture, and an undisplaced mid-sternal fracture, with a reported left breast tear pending confirmation.  Fifteen months post-accident, Ms. Slykhuis continues to present with a complex constellation of physical,   cognitive,   and   psycho-emotional   symptoms   that   profoundly   impact   her   daily functioning. Her physical symptoms are dominated by severe chest pain and pressure (rated  Veronique Slykhuis   Claim #: 1945485   Page 2 of 25

6-10/10) characterized by burning sensations and a pulling sensation extending from shoulder to shoulder. She experiences radiating pain from her lower back to her leg during ambulation, requiring the use of a single-point cane for stability. Her mobility is significantly compromised by balance impairments necessitating the use of supports during transfers, and she demonstrates a notably guarded gait pattern with reduced arm swing on the left side. Additional physical symptoms include left-sided headaches (6-8/10), cervical pain radiating to the left shoulder (4-8/10), left hand paresthesia, and persistent left ear tinnitus (8/10).  Cognitively, Ms. Slykhuis demonstrates significant impairments across multiple domains. Most notably, she exhibits pronounced executive dysfunction, evidenced by impaired judgment and impulse control in financial management. This is exemplified by recent episodes of compulsive online   shopping   and   gambling, resulting in substantial financial losses, and questionable purchasing decisions such as buying excessive quantities of unused items. Her memory deficits affect both recent event recall and prospective memory, impacting her ability to manage appointments and medications despite using organizational aids. She demonstrates marked difficulties with attention, concentration, and processing speed, becoming easily overwhelmed by multiple stimuli and requiring extended time to comprehend and respond to questions.  From a psycho-emotional perspective, Ms. Slykhuis presents with severe anxiety, particularly related to vehicular transportation, resulting in significant avoidance behaviors. She has not attempted to drive since the accident and becomes notably distressed when passing near the accident location. While she had a pre-existing history of depression that was well-managed pre-accident, her symptoms have intensified considerably, manifesting as frequent tearfulness, social withdrawal, and loss of interest in previously enjoyed activities. She exhibits pronounced post-traumatic   stress   symptoms   including   intrusive   thoughts,   flashbacks,   and   frequent nightmares that disrupt her sleep. Her emotional distress is compounded by significant sleep disruption, with multiple nighttime awakenings due to both pain and anxiety.  Prior to the accident, Ms. Slykhuis maintained full-time employment as a Customer Support Coordinator with the Standards Council of Canada (remote position) and part-time employment as a cashier at Independent Grocer, demonstrating her capacity to manage complex cognitive tasks and physical demands. She has been unable to return to either position due to her ongoing symptoms and functional limitations. The loss of employment has created additional financial   strain and emotional distress, particularly impacting her ability to maintain her previous standard of living and social engagement.  The cumulative impact of these impairments has resulted in a significant deterioration in Ms. Slykhuis's quality of life and independence. Her daily routine has become severely restricted, characterized by limited activity tolerance, frequent rest periods, and dependency on others for many basic activities of daily living. The interaction between her physical limitations, cognitive deficits, and emotional distress has created a self-perpetuating cycle that continues to impede her recovery and reintegration into her pre-accident roles and activities. FUNCTIONAL AND BEHAVIOURAL OBSERVATIONS:  During the assessment, Ms. Slykhuis presented as a well-groomed woman who appeared her stated age. She was oriented to person, place, and time, though she demonstrated some difficulty recalling specific dates and details of recent events. She engaged appropriately in the assessment process but required frequent breaks due to pain and fatigue. Her affect was generally flat, with periods of tearfulness when discussing the impact of the accident on her life. Her speech was clear but showed occasional word-finding difficulties and slowed processing speed.  Tolerances, Mobility and Transfers:  Ms. Slykhuis demonstrated significant limitations in her physical functioning during the assessment. When sitting, she could tolerate approximately 20-25 minutes before needing to change positions due to increasing pain. She was observed frequently shifting between positions and supporting her left chest area with her arm or a pillow. Even during these brief sitting periods, she displayed visible signs of discomfort including grimacing and guarding behaviors.  Bed mobility was observed to be significantly compromised. Ms. Slykhuis required multiple steps to transition from lying to sitting, frequently pausing due to pain. She demonstrated a consistent need to support her chest area during these movements and showed increased difficulty with movements to her left side.  Transfers were completed independently but with notable difficulty. When moving from sitting to standing, Ms. Slykhuis was observed to brace herself using nearby furniture and demonstrated a multi-step process that included pausing mid-transfer to manage pain. She required standby assistance during bathroom transfers and showed increased difficulty with lower surface heights such as the toilet. While she maintained independence with shower transfers, she demonstrated significant guarding behaviors and relied heavily on grab bars for support.  Walking was observed to be slow and deliberate, with Ms. Slykhuis adopting a guarded posture that favored her left side. She used a single-point cane for stability during ambulation and was observed to reach for walls or furniture when walking without the cane. Her walking endurance was limited to approximately 200 meters, after which she reported significant increases in pain and required rest. Her gait pattern showed evidence of compensation, with reduced arm swing on the left side and shortened step length.  Balance testing revealed impairments in both static and dynamic balance. Ms. Slykhuis demonstrated increased sway during quiet standing and required upper extremity support  Veronique Slykhuis   Claim #: 1945485   Page 11 of 25

during any reaching or bending activities. She was unable to perform tandem stance or single-leg stance due to instability and fear of falling. These balance impairments significantly impact her safety with daily activities and increase her risk for falls.  Active Range of Motion:  Range of motion testing revealed significant limitations, particularly in the trunk and upper body. Ms. Slykhuis demonstrated reduced cervical range of motion in all planes, with pain limiting end-range movements. Shoulder range of motion was notably restricted on the left side, with pain reported throughout the available range. Trunk mobility was severely limited, with Ms. Slykhuis unable to bend forward beyond approximately 30 degrees due to pain. She demonstrated compensatory movements when reaching or bending, often shifting her entire body rather than moving through her trunk.  Emotional Presentation:  Ms. Slykhuis's emotional presentation during the assessment was characterized by frequent shifts in affect. While she attempted to engage appropriately in the assessment process, she became tearful when discussing the impact of her injuries on her independence and ability to work. She appeared anxious when discussing transportation needs and future medical appointments. Her mood appeared to deteriorate as the assessment progressed and her pain and fatigue increased.  Cognitive Presentation:  Throughout the assessment, Ms. Slykhuis exhibited significant cognitive impairments that affected her participation and performance. Her information processing speed was markedly diminished, requiring extended time for question comprehension and response formulation. Her responses frequently digressed from the original topic, necessitating gentle redirection to maintain focus on assessment components. The increased cognitive demand of the assessment process appeared to compound her fatigue symptoms.  Of particular significance was a pattern of executive dysfunction that emerged during the recent holiday season. Ms. Slykhuis demonstrated poor judgment and impulsive behavior in her approach to holiday gift purchasing, acquiring numerous items without clear purpose or planning. This resulted in the accumulation of unopened packages and required significant therapeutic intervention to develop and implement an organized approach to gift distribution. Despite her pre-accident history of generous gift-giving, her current inability to independently modify this behavior or develop alternative strategies suggests a decline in problem-solving abilities and cognitive flexibility. Memory deficits were consistently observed throughout the assessment. Ms. Slykhuis relied heavily on written notes for basic information such as appointment dates and medication details. She demonstrated difficulty with temporal sequencing of recent events and showed inconsistent recall of medical appointments. Her attempts at independent problem-solving were often ineffective, requiring structured guidance to develop and implement practical solutions.  The assessment process revealed notable challenges with sustained attention and task persistence. These difficulties manifested in her need for frequent redirection and tendency to lose track of conversations, particularly as fatigue increased throughout the session. This presentation is consistent with her reported difficulties in managing daily activities and suggests a significant change from her pre-accident level of cognitive functioning.  A number of concerning behaviours demonstrating impulsivity, lack of judgement and lack of self-awareness we observed and documented later in this report under the financial management section. After returning home, she reports needing to lie down to recover from this activity.  She will make a simple breakfast shake or coffee and move to her living room sofa. She attempts to check emails but reports this is often challenging due to concentration difficulties and physical discomfort when sitting at her computer. She requires frequent position changes and often needs to lie down after 20-30 minutes of sitting upright.  Afternoon Activities: Around noon, she takes her dog out again, typically sitting outside while throwing a frisbee rather than walking due to increased pain and fatigue. She relies on reheating prepared foods for lunch as she reports difficulty with meal preparation tasks.  She typically needs to rest in bed around 1:00 PM, describing this as the time when her symptoms are most severe ("c'est la que ca frappe" –   “that’s when it hits me” ). After resting, she attempts some light housekeeping tasks such as loading/unloading the dishwasher or light tidying, but reports these activities often increase her pain significantly.
